Synthesis of a phosphomolybdic acid-modified AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 composite catalyst and its catalytic performance in the MTO reaction Jinbo Zhu Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Xu Chen Formal analysis Investigation Xiangge Sang Investigation Gang Yang Writing – review & editing ⁎ College of Chemical Engineering,Nanjing Tech University, State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing, Jiangsu 211800, China College of Chemical Engineering,Nanjing Tech University, State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering Nanjing Jiangsu 211800 China College of Chemical Engineering,Nanjing Tech University, State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing, Jiangsu 211800, China ⁎ Corresponding author. SAPO-34 catalysts with high selectivity for light olefins were first synthesized via the introduction of phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo) and AlPO4-5 zeolite into the initial gel. The physical and chemical characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were determined by a series of techniques and the catalytic performance of the modified composite zeolites for the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction was investigated. The results indicated that HPMo-modified SAPO-34 was featured with more Brønsted acid sites, more mesopores, and a smaller crystal size, thereby demonstrating superior catalytic performance. The further combination with AlPO4-5 (16.7 wt%) prolonged the lifetime of the HPMo-modified SAPO-34, which is thought in this paper related to its 12-ring straight channel (0.7–0.8 nm) and the absence of any Brønsted acid sites. The MTO tests showed that the light olefins selectivity for the modified composite zeolites reached 95.1 %, while the catalyst lifetime remained at 445 min Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords SAPO-34 AlPO4-5 Phosphomolybdic acid MTO Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene and propylene, which are light olefins that are typically produced through pyrolysis of petroleum, are significant raw materials in the petrochemical industry [1–4]. These common processes with high energy consumption and low light olefin production are heavily dependent on oil [2,5,6]. At present, with the global shortage of oil and the increase in oil prices, non-petroleum-based techniques for the production of light olefins have become increasingly desirable [7]. The MTO reaction for producing light olefins on zeolite catalysts is considered an ideal alternative to naphtha cracking, as methanol sources are widely available [1,2,8,9]. The SAPO-34 in the silicoaluminophosphate (SAPO) zeolite family shows high hydrothermal stability as well as shape-selective catalysis and particularly exhibits high selectivity for light olefins in the MTO reaction [10,11]. Nevertheless, the fast deactivation of the catalyst caused by coke deposition decreases its catalytic lifetime [12]. The main reason is that the product molecules that are not released from the pores in a timely manner can further polymerize to form coke deposition. The crystal size and pore diameter of zeolite influence the ability of reactant molecules to adsorb on the catalyst active site and the ability of product molecules to desorb from the pores. The smaller crystal size and larger pore facilitate the separation of product molecules, thereby preventing further reaction and carbon deposition [13,14]. Besides, Brønsted acidic sites are important driving forces for the MTO reaction. The generation and evolvement of reactive intermediates are heavily dependent on the acid sites of the SAPO-34 framework [12]. The weaker Brønsted acid sites slow the deposition of coke and improve the selectivity of light olefins[15]. Therefore, a small crystal size, more abundant mesopores and appropriate acidity can improve the catalytic performance and extend the lifetime of the SAPO-34 catalyst. Many efforts have been made to regulate the acidic properties of zeolites so as to improve the MTO reaction performance, typically accompanied by the introduction of metals, ion exchange, or dealumination [16–18]. To date, multiple metal ions, such as Fe, Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ce, Zr, La, Ca, Mg, and Zn, have been introduced in SAPO-34 to improve its catalytic performance [19–23]. The higher the acid strength of SAPO-34 is, the more coke deposits on the active sites, which leads to faster deactivation of the catalysts [24]. In general, the addition of metals into SAPO-34 decreases the strength of Brønsted acid. Therefore, SAPO-34 modified by metal exhibited a lower coke formation rate and a longer reactive lifetime. In addition to introducing different metals, the combination of two types of zeolites also regulated the acidic strength distribution of the zeolite [25]. AlPO4-5, the most famous member of the aluminium phosphate zeolite family, has high selectivity for methanol dehydration to dimethyl ether [26]. The pore size of AlPO4-5 is larger than that of SAPO-34, so the combination of them is more conducive to removing products from the catalyst. Heteropoly acids (HPAs), inorganic oxyacids with both acidity and redox properties, are widely used in catalysis, biology, energy and materials science fields [27,28]. HPA is an oxygen-containing polybasic acid that bridges through the coordination of oxygen atoms in specific structures through heteroatoms and polyatoms. 12-Phosphomolybdic acid (H3PMo12O40, HPMo), a Keggin-type HPA, has been widely studied because of its high acid strength, great stability and nontoxicity [29,30]. However, HPMo is generally not used directly as a solid acid catalyst due to its small surface area. Therefore, HPMo is typically used to load or modify other catalysts [31]. The usual approach to increase the HPA surface area is to load it on a zeolite, which has a porous structure and high specific surface area. To date, HPMo has been reported for loading onto or modifying zeolites such as SBA-15, MCM-48, Y zeolite and HZSM-5 [32–36]. However, there is currently no report on HPMo-modified SAPO-34 in the MTO reaction. In this study, a series of HPMo-modified SAPO-34 catalysts were synthesized by direct synthesis method. Furthermore, the HPMo-modified AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 composite zeolite catalysts were synthesized by directly introducing AlPO4-5 powder into the SAPO-34 gel. In this work, the optimal HPMo addition for enhancement of the catalytic performance of SAPO-34 and AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 for the MTO reaction was investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthetic material Tetraethyl ammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 25 wt%, Aladdin), orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4, 85 wt%, Aladdin), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99 wt%, Aladdin), aluminium isopropoxide (AIP, 98 wt%, Aladdin), phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (H3[P(Mo3O10)4]·xH2O, 99 wt%, Aladdin), and methanol (CH3OH, 99.99 wt%, Aladdin) were used. All solvents and chemicals were acquired from commercial sources. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of AlPO4-5 AlPO4-5 samples were prepared via a one-pot hydrothermal method with a 1.0 Al2O3:1.3 P2O5:1.2 TEAOH:205H2O molar composition. First, AlP was added to a TEAOH solution with deionized water under stirring at ambient temperature. After 4 h, H3PO4 was slowly dropped into the initial gel and stirred for 3 h. Then, the initial synthesis gel was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave, and a hydrothermal crystallization step was carried out at 185 °C for 24 h. After the crystallization process, the obtained solids were washed with deionized water and placed in an oven at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the dried solids were transferred to a 600 °C muffle furnace for calcination for 6 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of SAPO-34 The SAPO-34 samples were prepared with a gel molar composition of 0.5 Al2O3:0.4 SiO2:1.0 P2O5:2.0 TEAOH:x HPMo:70H2O. The values of x were 0, 0.009, 0.014 and 0.022. First, AlP was mixed with TEAOH and deionized water under stirring at ambient temperature. After stirring to uniformity, TEOS was dropped into the above solution and mixed for 30 min. Then, certain HPMo solids were dissolved in the synthesis gel under stirring. After 90 min of mixing, H3PO4 was gradually dripped into the mixture and stirred overnight. The composite SAPO-34 were prepared via adding 1 g AlPO4-5 powder into the synthesis gel as described above. Next, the obtained gel was subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 30 min at 25 °C and placed into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave to carry out hydrothermal crystallization at 200 °C for 48 h. After crystallization, the obtained samples were washed and transferred to a 110 °C oven for drying overnight. Finally, the dried SAPO-34 samples were placed in a muffle furnace and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. 2.3 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a MiniFlex600 (Rigaku, Japan) diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The 2θ range was from 5° to 80°. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICPAES) analysis of AlPO4-5 and SAPO-34 was performed on an Optima 7000DV (Perkin Elmer, USA). To prepare the test solution, 0.1 g of sample powder was digested in a solution composed of 1.5 mL of 40 wt% HF, 1 mL of 37 wt% HCl, 1 mL of 68 wt% HNO3 and 5 mL of H2O. The remaining HF was neutralized by adding 1.5 g of boric acid into solution. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded by means of a Nicolet8700 (Thermo, USA) within the range of 450–4000 cm−1. Diffuse reflectance UV–Vis spectroscopy (UV–vis/DRS) of the synthesized catalysts was performed by means of a UV-3600i Plus (Shimadzu, Japan) scanning spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed by means of a S-4800 (Hitachi, Japan) to observe the morphology of the SAPO-34 samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a JEM-2100Plus (JEOL, Japan) to further analyse the morphology of SAPO-34. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was performed on an ASAP2460 (Micromeritics, USA). Pyrolysis-infrared spectroscopy (py-IR) was performed on Tensor 27 (Bruker, Germany) to determine the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites of catalysts. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on an AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) to measure the acidity of the catalysts. Before the test, 0.1 g of zeolite particles (40–60 mesh) were pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h under a He atmosphere. After pretreatment, the system temperature decreased to 100 °C, and the catalyst samples absorbed ammonia for 2 h. Then, the samples were flushed with He gas flow to remove excess ammonia. Finally, ammonia molecules were removed at a heating rate of 10 °C/min to 600 °C. 2.4 Catalytic performance test The MTO reaction was conducted in a tubular fixed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. The diagram of the experimental device for the MTO reaction is illustrated in Fig. 1. Before the MTO reaction, 1.5 g of the catalyst sample (20–40 mesh) was loaded into a stainless steel tube. The zeolite particles were fixed in the middle of the reactor with quartz sands. After the catalyst was prepared, the catalyst was pretreated under a N2 gas flow at 550 °C for 1 h. Then, the system temperature was decreased to 450 °C, and 40 wt% methanol was introduced into the reactor. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 40 wt% methanol was 4 h−1. The gaseous products were analysed by means of a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a capillary column (HP-AL/S, 50 m × 0.53 mm × 15 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). After the reaction, the deactivated catalysts were calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h to remove most of coke deposits. The air flow rate was 50 mL/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD characterization It can be seen in Fig. 2, the characteristic diffractions of the SAPO-34 samples at 2θ = 9.5°, 13.8°, 16.2°, 20.5°, and 30.8° were attributed to its chabazite (CHA) structure [37]. In the XRD pattern of SAPO-34 modified by HPMo, the intensity of the characteristic peak of SAPO-34 decreased slightly, possibly due to a decrease in the crystallinity. This indicated that the addition of HPMo into synthesis gel decreased the crystallinity of SAPO-34 but did not destroy the CHA structure. In addition, SAPO-34 samples compounded with AlPO4-5 exhibited (1 0 0) crystal plane characteristic peaks of AlPO4-5. These results suggested that AlPO4-5 was successfully incorporated with SAPO-34. However, the AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 samples modified by HPMo significantly decreased the intensity of the (1 0 0) crystal plane characteristic peaks of AlPO4-5. This result indicated that the modification of HPMo caused partial damage to the AlPO4-5 crystals lattice. 3.2 ICPAES analysis ICPAES analysis was used to determine the elemental proportion of the synthesized catalysts. The Si/Al molar ratio, P/Al molar ratio and Mo contents of the synthesized catalysts are shown in Table 1. As the amount of HPMo increased, the Mo contents of the samples gradually increased. However, the proportions of Mo in these samples were still extremely low, suggesting that Mo could not enter the SAPO-34 skeleton, but a small portion remained in the channels of SAPO-34 in the form of an oxide. 3.3 UV–vis/DRS analysis Fig. 3 shows the UV–vis/DRS spectra of the three synthesized samples. The spectra of all of the prepared SAPO-34 samples illustrated a broad band in the range of 200–360 nm, which was attributed to the Al-O charge transfer transition in the AlO4 species of the skeleton [38]. In addition, compared with the spectrum of the parent sample, that of SAPO-34 modified by HPMo exhibited a band at approximately 213 nm, which was recognized as a characteristic band of tetrahedrally coordinated Mo(Ⅵ) [39]. By considering these results with the ICP results, the molybdenum oxide species were determined to be located in the channels of SAPO-34 zeolite in the form of tetrahedral coordination [40]. 3.4 SEM analysis Fig. 4 illustrates the SEM pictures of the synthesized samples. All the samples revealed a spherical morphology composed of a loose stack of ultrasmall cubic nanocrystals. Spherical aggregates of SAPO-34 cubic nanocrystals were synthesized without the use of ultrasound treatment or quaternary ammonium-type organosilane surfactant, which was attributed to the higher Si/TEAOH ratio [41]. Furthermore, SAPO-34 modified by HPMo exhibited smaller spherical aggregates of cubic nanocrystals than the parent sample. A small amount of HPMo contributed to the generation of smaller cubic nanocrystals. As the amount of HPMo continued to increase, although the particle size of the synthesized zeolite samples further decreased, the number of irregular crystals increased. The reason for this finding is that the addition of metal species into the synthetic gel decreased the growth rate of the crystal to be less than its nucleation rate [37]. This means that the solution tended to supersaturate and created smaller SAPO-34 particles [42]. AlPO4-5 with a hexagonal rod-shaped structure was not found in Fig. 4e–h, as it was tightly coated by SAPO-34 nanocrystals. However, on basis of the XRD characterization results, SAPO-34 composite samples presented the (1 0 0) crystal plane feature of AlPO4-5. And the corresponding relationships of other diffraction peak positions were not evident. One possible reason is that the both ends of the longer AlPO4-5, after being coated by SAPO-34 nanocrystals, are exposed on the surface of spherical aggregates. 3.5 TEM analysis Fig. 5 illustrates TEM results for the HPMo1-SAPO-34 and HPMo1-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 samples. All the samples exhibited ultrasmall nanocrystallites with a size of approximately 40–100 nm. It was clearly observed that the samples were constructed by the self-assembly of cubic nanocrystals. Because of the solid interior of the aggregates, it was difficult to observe the internal structures of the samples, whereas the edged complete cubic crystals were still visible. These results confirmed that the samples were constructed from cubic-like nanocrystals. In addition, the stacking between particles created a mesoporous structure, which could be used to explain the BET results described below. 3.6 BET analysis Fig. 6(a) exhibits the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the samples. As shown in this figure, all the samples except the parent SAPO-34 showed I- and IV-type isotherms, indicating the existence of a hierarchical pore structure. Furthermore, According to Fig. 6(b) and Table 2, the introduction of HPMo resulted in the formation of more 2–5 nm mesopores in SAPO-34, while the combination of AlPO4-5 provided more 5–40 nm mesopores for SAPO-34, which increased the average pore diameter. The additional mesoporous structure facilitated the separation of the product molecules from the catalysts, which prevented further reactions and decreased the formation of carbon deposits. Thus, the pore size distribution of SAPO-34 can be regulated by adding HPMo and AlPO4-5. In addition, the samples combined with AlPO4-5 had higher BET surface areas than the parent sample. 3.7 Py-IR and NH3-TPD analysis The acidic properties of the prepared zeolite samples are exhibited in Fig. 7 and Table 3. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, two infrared absorption peaks presented around 1450 cm−1 and 1540 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine coordinated with Lewis acid sites and pyridine cation bound with Brønsted acid sites, respectively [43]. According to Fig. 7b, the NH3-TPD profile of the AlPO4-5 sample showed an ammonia desorption peak centred at 140 °C for weak acid sites. Furthermore, it can be observed that the curves of SAPO-34 showed two ammonia desorption peaks centred at 150–170 °C and 340–350 °C, corresponding to weak acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively. The first ammonia desorption peak was attributed to hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, including P–OH, Si–OH and Al–OH (Lewis acids), while the second ammonia desorption peak was due to Si–OH–Al (Brønsted acids) [44]. The generation of dimethyl ether (DME) mainly occurred at Lewis acid sites, and the DME to olefins reaction occurred at Brønsted acid sites [45]. Therefore, Brønsted acid sites played a critical role in the MTO reaction. Nevertheless, excessive Brønsted acids led to the generation of more coke and facilitated inactivation. In addition, regarding the SAPO-34 samples, the number of Brønsted acid sites was far less than the number of Lewis acid sites due to the lower Si/(Al+P) molar ratio. AlPO4-5 possessed few weak acid sites and no strong acid site, indicating that it can only catalyze the conversion of the methanol dehydration to DME. The modification of SAPO-34 by HPMo slightly increased the density of Brønsted acids due to a small amount of molybdenum oxide, whereas AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 had a slightly reduced Brønsted acid density. Therefore, the Brønsted acid density of SAPO-34 was regulated by adding HPMo and AlPO4-5. 3.8 FTIR analysis The FTIR spectra of the prepared zeolite samples are illustrated in Fig. 8. The peaks at 490 cm−1 were ascribed to PO4, AlO4 as well as SiO4 bending vibrations [46]. The infrared absorption peaks at 640 cm−1 were attributed to the D-6 ring structure of SAPO-34. The asymmetric and symmetric vibration peaks of O-P-O were located at 640 cm−1 and 710 cm−1, respectively [24]. In addition, the infrared absorption peaks at approximately 1630 cm−1 were assigned to physically adsorbed water on the sample surface [2]. The wide peaks at approximately 3450 cm−1 corresponded to hydroxyl stretching vibrations, including Al-OH, P-OH, Si-OH groups (Lewis acid) as well as Si-OH-Al groups (Brønsted acid) [47]. Upon introduction of HPMo into SAPO-34, the area of the 3450 cm−1 absorption peaks increased, indicating that HPMo-modified SAPO-34 samples had more acid sites than the parent. This coincided with the NH3-TPD results. The FTIR spectra of HPMo1-SAPO-34 exhibited an absorption peak at 870 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of MoO [48]. This band implied that Mo had been incorporated into HPMo-modified SAPO-34 in the form of oxides, consistent with the UV–vis/DRS results. However, due to the increase in transmittance of AlPO4-5 at 870 cm−1 and the low Mo content (0.025 wt%), the spectrum of HPMo1-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 did not exhibit the stretching vibrations of MoO. 3.9 Catalytic performance test Fig. 9a and c demonstrate the relationship between the methanol conversion rate and the reaction time. Initially, all the synthesized SAPO-34 samples exhibited high methanol conversion near 100 %. Then, upon deactivation of the catalysts, methanol conversion began to decrease and followed different trends. The primary reason was the deposition of coke in the catalyst, which led to pore plugging and acid site poisoning [49]. The formation of coke was ascribed to the deposition of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in cages [50]. According to Fig. 9 and Table 4, SAPO-34 modified by HPMo or combined with AlPO4-5 had a longer lifetime due to the presence of more mesopores than in the parent SAPO-34. Among these samples, the HPMo1-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 sample had the longest catalytic life, which reached 460 min. In addition, as shown in Fig. 9b and Fig. 9d, the modified SAPO-34 samples had higher selectivity for the target products than conventional SAPO-34. Notably, the modified samples exhibited different selectivity for ethylene and propylene. As listed in Table 4, the introduction of HPMo into SAPO-34 increased the selectivity of ethylene and decreased the selectivity of propylene, which was possibly attributed to the promotion of Mo species to the direct non-oxidative coupling of methane. It was also reported that when the relatively abundant olefins or higher alkanes were in the reaction, the methane could be highly activated at low temperature (400–600 °C) [51]. However, as HPMo addition continued, the number of mesopores of SAPO-34 further increased, and the selectivity of propylene increased faster than that of ethylene. The abundant mesopores of SAPO-34 were not conducive to the formation of ethylene, which requires smaller intermediates [52]. Furthermore, more mesopores are beneficial for the generation of propylene. On this basis, HPMo-SAPO-34 compounded with AlPO4-5 further provided larger and more mesopores, resulting in higher propylene selectivity and the same ethylene selectivity as the parent SAPO-34. The larger mesopores brought by AlPO4-5 also promoted the generation of C4+ hydrocarbons. Based on Table 4, the HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 sample exhibited a long catalytic lifetime of 445 min and the highest light olefin selectivity of 95.13 %. The optimal catalytic performance of HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 benefited from its high specific surface area, ultrasmall nanocrystallites, hierarchical pore structure and suitable acid strength. The catalytic performance of the regenerated HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 and product distribution are illustrated in Fig. 10 and Table 5, respectively. As shown in Fig. 10a, all samples showed a nearly 100 % methanol conversion at the beginning of the MTO reaction. However, with the regeneration times increased, the samples exhibited a faster deactivation rate. After the fourth regeneration, the lifetime of the modified composite catalyst shortened from 445 min to 260 min, which could be attributed to internal unremoved coke deposits and/or the damage of crystalline structure. In addition, as shown in Fig. 10b and Table 5, the light olefins selectivity of HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 decreased after each regeneration. It was noteworthy that with the regeneration times increased, the selectivity of ethylene improved and the selectivity of propylene decreased. The result indicated that a small amount of coke deposits was conducive to ethylene formation or suppressed the generation of propylene. The presence of internal coke deposition made the higher olefins not diffuse so to evolve into active aromatic substances, which is encouraging the aromatics-ethylene route [53]. This also explains the decrease in propylene selectivity and the increase in methane selectivity. Fig. 11 exhibits the comparison of catalytic performance between the synthesized catalysts proposed in our work with other highly selective modified-SAPO-34 reported in the literature. The modified SAPO-34 with high light olefins selectivity usually possess short lifetime in the MTO reaction. As shown in Fig. 11, the SAPO-34 modified by the method described in this work exhibited a higher selectivity for light olefins than other modified SAPO-34 while maintaining a relatively long lifetime. 3.10 Characterization of regenerated catalysts A series of characterizations were performed on the HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 samples after fifth regeneration. It can be observed in SEM image ( Fig. 12a) that the small SAPO-34 crystals are destroyed heavily whereas the crystalline structure of the large particles are relatively complete. This indicates that nanoparticles exhibited the poorer mechanical strength compared to the large SAPO-34 particles. As shown in Fig. 12b, the diffraction peak intensity of the regenerated catalyst decreased deeply compared to the fresh, which was also implied that the destruction of SAPO-34 crystalline structure. The N2 sorption isotherms and the pore size distribution of the fresh and the regenerated sample are illustrated in Fig. 12c and d, respectively. As shown in Fig. 12c, I-type sorption saturation of the regenerated catalyst reduced heavily compared to the fresh, which signified the decrease of micropores because of the occupation of residual coke. It can be also seen in Fig. 12d that the number of micropores in the regenerated catalyst decreases. Besides, catalyst regenerated five times appeared macropores (>50 nm) structure, which was attributed to the destruction of SAPO-34 crystalline structure. 4 Conclusion The effects of phosphomolybdic acid (H3PMo12O40) and AlPO4-5 zeolite on the SAPO-34 catalytic performance were considered. The introduction of an appropriate amount of HPMo (x = 0.014) into the initial gel led to an increase in the mesoporous structure, a decrease in particle size, and an increase in Brønsted acid sites. As determined from the MTO catalytic test, SAPO-34 modified by HPMo showed a longer catalytic lifetime as well as the higher selectivity for the target products. Moreover, HPMo2-SAPO-34 compounded with 1.0 g of AlPO4-5 maintained desirable acidic properties and further increased the amount and size of mesopores, which showed a long lifetime of 445 min and the highest target product selectivity of 95.13 %. All the tests indicated that the introduction of HPMo and AlPO4-5 into the SAPO-34 catalyst improved its pore size distribution, the number of acid sites and the catalytic performance. Then, HPMo2-AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 samples with the best catalytic performance were conducted on regeneration test. The sample regenerated five times was characterized by a series of techniques. It is indicated that the light olefins selectivity of the fourth regenerated sample decreased slightly, whereas the lifetime reduced heavily. This is attributed to the destruction of SAPO-34 crystalline structure and the occupation of residual coke in the pores. It is worth noting that the presence of residual coke is beneficial for ethylene formation. coredata.dc:description: SAPO-34 catalysts with high selectivity for light olefins were first synthesized via the introduction of phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo) and AlPO4-5 zeolite into the initial gel. The physical and chemical characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were determined by a series of techniques and the catalytic performance of the modified composite zeolites for the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction was investigated. The results indicated that HPMo-modified SAPO-34 was featured with more Brønsted acid sites, more mesopores, and a smaller crystal size, thereby demonstrating superior catalytic performance. The further combination with AlPO4-5 (16.7 wt%) prolonged the lifetime of the HPMo-modified SAPO-34, which is thought in this paper related to its 12-ring straight channel (0.7–0.8 nm) and the absence of any Brønsted acid sites. The MTO tests showed that the light olefins selectivity for the modified composite zeolites reached 95.1 %, while the catalyst lifetime remained at 445 min
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of a phosphomolybdic acid-modified AlPO4-5/SAPO-34 composite catalyst and its catalytic performance in the MTO reaction
